For actiones utiles see the pages referred to s. v. ‘actiones directae et utiles² in the General Indeic The operation of the senatusconsult was much narrowed eleven years later by the enactment of the SC. Pegasianum, which (inter alia) provided (1) that fideicommissa should in future be subject to the rule which bad been established for legacies by the lex Falcidia, and the heir be entitled to retain for himself a fourth of the inheritance clear of fideicommissa. (2) T hat where fideicommissa were charged upon an inheritance in exc'ess of three-fourths of its value, the SC. Trebellianum should have no application. The general result after this was as follows:

(1) lf the fideicommissa did not exceed three-fourths of the whole suc· cession, the transfer of those of them which were ‘hereditates' was govemed by the SC. Trebellianum: the transferee became quasi-heir (as described in ξ 4) and could sue and be sued by utilis actio in respect of the share he toolr: no stipulations between him and the heres directus were required.

(2) If the fideicommissa, whether singular or universal, exceededthree- fourths of the hereditas, the only person who could sue and be sued was the heres directus, the SC. Trebellianum being excluded. Accord- ingly, it was necessary to go back to the old contract of indemnification: else the heir would in all probability find the hereditas damnosa The exact matter of the contract, however, as is remarked in td, differed according as the heir availed himself of the SC. Pegasianum, and re- tained his fourth, or was unable or declined to take advantage of it.
